newsitem.title: UK: MOTOR RACING-WILLIAMS TURN TO FRENTZEN TO COUNTER FERRARI.
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-WILLIAMS TURN TO FRENTZEN TO COUNTER FERRARI.

text.p: The Williams Formula One team, fearing a Ferrari renaissance, named Heinz-Harald Frentzen on Wednesday as their replacement for championship leader Damon Hill.
The 29-year-old German joins Canadian Jacques Villeneuve next year, ousting Hill from the team just when the Briton is within touching distance of his first Grand Prix drivers' title.
Hill is 13 points clear of Villeneuve with three races to go and could clinch the drivers' crown in Sunday's Italian Grand Prix at Monza.
Williams, who has developed a reputation for brutally parting company with successful drivers, gave no reason for the decision to drop Hill, who had been with the Anglo-French team for six years.

But in an interview published in the British magazine Motoring News on Wednesday, Frank Williams spoke of his fear of a renaissance at rivals Ferrari, spearheaded by twice world champion Michael Schumacher.

"In all this you must recognise one thing: you have not seen the best of Michael," he said. "The nightmare is to picture Michael in a car next year that is as competitive as the Williams presently is. We will all have to go to church on Sunday and pray for unreliability."
The German previously transformed the Benetton team, beating Hill to the world drivers' title with them in 1994 and 1995, before joining Ferrari.

"It's not on the agenda today, but of course I would love to see Schumacher in a Willliams like we always wanted to see Ayrton (Senna) in one," Williams added. "He is a phenomenon in a Grand Prix car...he is quite remarkable."
Frentzen, currently with Sauber, has not won a Grand Prix, but is regarded as one of the fastest drivers on the circuit and a fitting challenger for Schumacher.
He has become known on the Grand Prix circuit as "the other German", especially as his former girlfriend left him in 1991 for Schumacher. She is now Schumacher's wife.

Frentzen won the German junior championship and other titles between 1980 and 1985 before climbing via Formula Ford and the Opel Lotus series to finish as runner-up in the German Formula Three series in 1989.
He has been a target for the Anglo-French Williams team for some time despite the fact that this season he has managed only six world championship points and is just 11th in the standings.
For Hill, who was dropped by Williams after contract negotiations broke down last week, a move to the British Jordan team appears the most likely option.
The 35-year-old plans to give a news conference at Monza on Thursday to talk about his plans.
